speaker: SHALLOW
text: By cock and pie, sir, you shall not away

speaker: SHALLOW
text: tonight.—What, Davy, I say!

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: You must excuse me, Master Robert Shallow.

speaker: SHALLOW
text: I will not excuse you. You shall not be

speaker: SHALLOW
text: excused. Excuses shall not be admitted. There is no

speaker: SHALLOW
text: excuse shall serve. You shall not be excused.—

speaker: SHALLOW
text: Why, Davy!

speaker: DAVY
text: Here, sir.

speaker: SHALLOW
text: Davy, Davy, Davy, Davy, let me see, Davy, let

speaker: SHALLOW
text: me see, Davy, let me see. Yea, marry, William cook,

speaker: SHALLOW
text: bid him come hither.—Sir John, you shall not be

speaker: SHALLOW
text: excused.

speaker: DAVY
text: Marry, sir, thus: those precepts cannot be served.

speaker: DAVY
text: And again, sir: shall we sow the hade land with

speaker: DAVY
text: wheat?

speaker: SHALLOW
text: With red wheat, Davy. But for William cook,

speaker: SHALLOW
text: are there no young pigeons?

speaker: DAVY
text: Yes, sir. Here is now the smith’s note for shoeing

speaker: DAVY
text: and plow irons.

speaker: SHALLOW
text: Let it be cast and paid.—Sir John, you shall

speaker: SHALLOW
text: not be excused.

speaker: DAVY
text: Now, sir, a new link to the bucket must needs be

speaker: DAVY
text: had. And, sir, do you mean to stop any of William’s

speaker: DAVY
text: wages about the sack he lost the other day at

speaker: DAVY
text: Hinckley Fair?

speaker: SHALLOW
text: He shall answer it. Some pigeons, Davy, a

speaker: SHALLOW
text: couple of short-legged hens, a joint of mutton, and

speaker: SHALLOW
text: any pretty little tiny kickshaws, tell William cook.

speaker: DAVY
text: Doth the man of war stay all night, sir?

speaker: SHALLOW
text: Yea, Davy, I will use him well. A friend i’ th’

speaker: SHALLOW
text: court is better than a penny in purse. Use his men

speaker: SHALLOW
text: well, Davy, for they are arrant knaves and will

speaker: SHALLOW
text: backbite.

speaker: DAVY
text: No worse than they are back-bitten, sir, for they

speaker: DAVY
text: have marvelous foul linen.

speaker: SHALLOW
text: Well-conceited, Davy. About thy business,

speaker: SHALLOW
text: Davy.

speaker: DAVY
text: I beseech you, sir, to countenance William Visor

speaker: DAVY
text: of Woncot against Clement Perkes o’ th’ hill.

speaker: SHALLOW
text: There is many complaints, Davy, against that

speaker: SHALLOW
text: Visor. That Visor is an arrant knave, on my

speaker: SHALLOW
text: knowledge.

speaker: DAVY
text: I grant your Worship that he is a knave, sir, but

speaker: DAVY
text: yet, God forbid, sir, but a knave should have some

speaker: DAVY
text: countenance at his friend’s request. An honest

speaker: DAVY
text: man, sir, is able to speak for himself when a knave is

speaker: DAVY
text: not. I have served your Worship truly, sir, this eight

speaker: DAVY
text: years; an I cannot once or twice in a quarter bear

speaker: DAVY
text: out a knave against an honest man, I have but a

speaker: DAVY
text: very little credit with your Worship. The knave is

speaker: DAVY
text: mine honest friend, sir; therefore I beseech you let

speaker: DAVY
text: him be countenanced.

speaker: SHALLOW
text: Go to, I say, he shall have no wrong. Look

speaker: SHALLOW
text:
about, Davy. 
                Davy
                 
                exits
                .
               Where are you, Sir John?

speaker: SHALLOW
text: Come, come, come, off with your boots.—Give me

speaker: SHALLOW
text: your hand, Master Bardolph.

speaker: BARDOLPH
text: I am glad to see your Worship.

speaker: SHALLOW
text: I thank thee with all my heart, kind Master

speaker: SHALLOW
text:
Bardolph,
                 
                (
                to
                 
                Page
                )
               and welcome, my tall

speaker: SHALLOW
text: fellow.—Come, Sir John.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: I’ll follow you, good Master Robert Shallow.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text:
Shallow
                 
                exits
                .
               Bardolph, look to our horses.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: If I were sawed into quantities,

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: I should make four dozen of such bearded hermits’

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: staves as Master Shallow. It is a wonderful thing to

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: see the semblable coherence of his men’s spirits

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: and his. They, by observing of him, do bear

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: themselves like foolish justices; he, by conversing

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: with them, is turned into a justice-like servingman.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: Their spirits are so married in conjunction with the

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: participation of society that they flock together in

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: consent like so many wild geese. If I had a suit to

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: Master Shallow, I would humor his men with the

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: imputation of being near their master; if to his men,

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: I would curry with Master Shallow that no man

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: could better command his servants. It is certain

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: that either wise bearing or ignorant carriage is

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: caught, as men take diseases, one of another. Therefore

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: let men take heed of their company. I will

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: devise matter enough out of this Shallow to keep

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: Prince Harry in continual laughter the wearing out

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: of six fashions, which is four terms, or two actions,

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: and he shall laugh without intervallums. O, it is

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: much that a lie with a slight oath and a jest with a

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: sad brow will do with a fellow that never had the

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: ache in his shoulders. O, you shall see him laugh till

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: his face be like a wet cloak ill laid up.

speaker: SHALLOW
text: Sir John.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: I come, Master Shallow, I come, Master

speaker: FALSTAFF
text: Shallow.
